Figure 6 shows the distance-dependent correlation $C(d)$ on the stock distance for the three periods, i.e., before, in and after the financial crisis. It is observed that the $C(d)$ decays with the stock distance before the financial crisis, but is independent of the stock distance in and after the financial crisis. That is to say, in the normal financial stage, the stocks located close to each other have a more compact correlation than those located far way. But the distance effect disappears when the market encounters the financial crisis. To confirm the results, the dependence of the stock correlation on the stock distance is also investigated for the shuffled series. As shown in Fig. 7, the $C(d)$ of the shuffled data is observed to keep stable for different stock distances even in the normal market stage of the year 2005-2006, which is different from the results of the real market.


\section*{Conclusion}

The geography and distance effect on financial dynamics is investigated, based on the daily data of the individual stocks of the Chinese stock market. The financial center is found to still play an important role in stock dynamics, and the stocks located in the Shanghai city and the Guangdong province contribute greatly to the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets, respectively. The geographical correlation is introduced, which is found to be less fluctuated as the stock location moves to the northeast China. The stock distance distribution is studied, and is observed to obey a two-stage exponential decay, indicating that the companies incline to set their headquarters close to each other. Moreover, the stock distance is found to affect the stock correlation only in the normal market environment, but rarely influence the stock correlation in and after the financial crisis.
